name: About LAN Academy
body:
![](http://media.tumblr.com/d8e20f0fd17052e6d4365d50a41be8c9/tumblr_inline_mouabhYTLC1qawmfj.png) ## What we do: LAN Academy is a nonprofit committed to bringing high-quality education around the world through simple, cheap, and offline learning labs. These learning labs are established through partnerships between LAN Academy and locally-active non-profits. Local partners provide a physical space, guidance, and mentorship to students. LAN Academy provides our "Magic Box": a small offline server filled with the best educational content the world has to offer. Our Learning Labs bring the digital learning revolution to ones who need it the most - the 4.5 billion people in the world without internet access. ## Our Vision > ## **“Access to education is a crucial precondition to educational impact, but what matters most thereafter is the quality of education.” _- USAID strategy (February 2011)_** We believe high-quality education is the best way to bring people out of poverty and that it is possible to do this on a global scale  by making the online abundance of quality educational materials accessible to underprivileged students through a worldwide network of partners who care about their local communities. At our heart, we embrace exploratory learning - the idea that it is possible for learning to feel natural and unforced by allowing students take control of their own learning. We believe that knowledge is rich and multidimensional and that different students learn in very different ways. The curiosity and unique interests of each student are what make our Learning Labs such a powerful education system. ## Why LAN Academy? Quality education is critical to realizing human potential, but schools in poverty-stricken regions are often ill-equipped, overcrowded, and unable to teach students beyond a basic level. NGOs working in these communities understand the need, but current education investment options are either costly or otherwise not ideal. New education technology such as MOOCs have potential, but most students who need educational intervention lack reliable internet access. LAN Academy is built for exactly these situations. Partner NGOs provide the physical space and lab supervision. We provide a fundraising campaign to cover the hardware costs. Our products and Learning Lab model allow the neediest students access to some of the best educators in the world. ## Our Impact Is this really an effective system? How do you know you are making an impact? Impact measurement is a concern for every socially-minded venture, especially for ones as ambitious as we are. We work continuously to perfect our education model, but from the very beginning we have based our efforts off the works of cutting edge education researchers such as TED Fellow Sugata Mitra, whose work can be seen [this article](http://www.hole-in-the-wall.com/docs/Paper13.pdf) he published in 2010 and in this  [outline](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dk60sYrU2RU&feature=player_detailpage#t=399s) of his research. Our Learning Labs build off this research and are our attempt to answer the question: “But what about the students who do not have reliable internet access?” We think we are on the right track. As we expand, we will be constantly performing our own openly-available research on exactly how effective our specific setup is across countries and cultures. ## Current Partners: In 2012, we partnered with **African Indian Alliance** to install two labs in Karnataka, India. Field reports indicate that the current labs are popular and having an impact. We are in the midst of returning Summer 2013 to gather data, update labs, and install two additional labs in nearby villages. Visit the [Collaborate With Us](lanacademy.org/collaborate) page to learn more and to express interest in becoming a new partner.
## Team **Full-Time:** John Williams (CEO) is the vision behind LAN Academy. He dropped out of “school” in 6th grade and has been teaching himself and others ever since. He has taught AP World History and MIT Hssp, unofficially interned in MIT labs, and started his first nonprofit (a self-sustaining network of high school computer clubs) when he was 15 years old. He is currently studying at Northeastern University. **Current Part-Time Volunteers:** Clark Andrews (Co-founder) - Purchasing and Finances. Part of the original team of the Indian LAN Academy project, Clark has also built houses with John in Belize and New Orleans. A student at the Isenberg School of Management, Clark runs a number of other high-value business in the field of online retail and e-currency operations. Eric Marriott – Our Lead Programmer. Another student who followed a non-traditional education journey, Eric is a Biotechnology major who has studied everywhere from Middlesex Community College to the Harvard Extension school. He is currently a student at Northeastern University. Natalia Davé – Our Donations Manager. Also at Northeastern University, Natalia brings on-the-ground experience from her time as a student in Guyana, as well as an astounding drive and ability to get things done. Kayla O'Neill – Our ever-eloquent wordsmith, Kayla has an incredible ability to make sense of all of our ideas and plans and put them down in writing. She also assists with our blog and Facebook page. Kayla is currently studying International Business at Northeastern University. ## Advisors Pash Obeng – CEO of African Indian Alliance; Associate Professor of African Studies, Wellesley College Bob Tomasetti – VP Business Development, Acumentrics Gordon Adomdza – Assistant Professor of Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Northeastern University
